reviewText: OK - had to get one more review out there = this is one of the most enjoyable All-Star concert DVDs I have ever seen!  This was originally staged in Late 1992, then broadcast on HBO and then PBS.  It's hard to believe this concert happened over twenty years ago.  Prior to this event, it seemed that Dylan had been in a slight 'slump' - but soon after, by the mid-1990's Dylan would be back in true-form again (especially with multi-Grammy winning 'Time-Out-of-Mind' in 1997!).But this 1992 concert was a great Celebration, and amazing opportunity for all those stellar Poet/Rockers (or just plain Rockers!) that had been positively influenced by Bob Dylan (they seemed too numerous to count) ==> to put on an awesome Show => full of imaginative and inspired 'covers' of many of Dylan's best Songs, over the previous 30 Years!There really are too many Great performances to mention individually but I will still try:Chrissie Hynde's rendition of 'I Shall be Released' Elevated this song to one of the most powerful ever written & performed (and G.E. Smith's guitar work = amazing!);  Stevie Wonder's 'Blowin' in the Wind' (in many ways this song is much more resonant when done in the R&B;/Soul style!);  Johnny Winter's 'Highway 61 Revisited' = couldn't understand the Words, but who cares - positively electrifying (could actually see the 'sparks' fly!);  Ron Wood's 'Seven Days' Wood took what seemed to be a mediocre song, and made it a rowdy Rock Classic!  Nanci Griffiths' 'Boots of Spanish Leather' incredibly poignant, it's a shame that this was cut-out of earlier Videos and not on the original CD (being an authentic reflection of Dylan's original Folk roots!);And the Last two performances are way Beyond Awesome = 'My Back Pages' (with full Lyrics!) ==> Eric Claptons' (and even Neil Young's) guitar solos are some of the Best ever, and nearly everyone gets a turn at the mike, with a chance to sing these mystifyingly prophetic & poetic lyrics!And finally, 'Knockin' on Heaven's Door' this is as close as you will ever come to authentically 'Spiritual' Rock!note:  I did actually see Dylan in 1998 when he played a relatively small concert at Andrew's Amphitheater, on the grounds of the UH (Dylan was in Top-form again, by that Time!).  He's coming back to HI in April, but I did not secure Tickets (but at Least I have this invaluable re-issued DVD to see & hear again!)
summary: Next Best thing to Being There - perhaps Even Better considering Bob Dylan's Super-Star 'back-up' Group!!!

reviewText: Bob Dylan/Various Artists"30th Anniversary Concert Celebration" (CD & DVD)(Sony Legacy, 2014). . . .This four-disc CD/DVD set documents a massive 1992 celeb-fest concert honoring Bob Dylan's career, with live performances by rock, pop, country and folk stars of the era, as well as numerous old-guard artists who were Dylan's contemporaries in the '60s.  The stage is set by an excellent introductory sequence in which we see Dylan in a career-spanning montage, as well warm testimonials from many of the artists who played at the Madison Square Garden show, and then the concert is presented from start to finish with guitarist G.E. Smith leading the on-stage backing band and splitting emcee duties with Kris Kristofferson and others.How you see these performances will depend largely on how you viewed the music scene of the time, the early '90s representing an era when post-punk "grunge" had revitalized rock'n'roll, but the '80s vibe was still strong, as seen by performers such as Tom Petty, John Mellencamp, et. al. One way to view this is as a triumphal last gasp for the hippie-era rock elite: there's Dylan of course, but he wound up being timeless and immortal, but also Eric Clapton, who was riding high on his own "Unplugged" triumphs and Neil Young, who bangs through a couple of classics much to the delight of the crowd and one of the concert's biggest surprises is how Ron Wood brings the house down with his tight, dynamic version of "Seven Days," crisply summoning the intensity of his youth and showing the young folk how it's done.Another striking moment comes when Irish singer Sinead O'Connor comes out and is basically booed off the stage, appearing in concert shortly after she publicly criticized the Pope and the Catholic hierarchy for covering up rampant sexual abuse within the Church -- an issue on which she was resoundingly vindicated, two decades later.  The instant O'Connor steps on stage, the crowd erupts into an epic battle of fierce cheers and persistent boos. Instead of singing a Dylan song, she defiantly and tearfully barks out a rough version of the adapted Bob Marley song she had sung on Saturday Night Live two weeks earlier that had caused all the controversy in the first place... One of the few differences between the CD and DVD versions of the "Bobfest" concert is her performance: on the CD we hear her in rehearsal, singing "I Believe In You," and the inclusion of concert video is certainly appreciated, though it is a bit jarring to see how quickly the show went on as if nothing had ever happened when one of their fellow performers had been so dramatically confronted by the audience.Dylan fans will dig this one, and students of pop culture will appreciate the snapshot of the rock'n'pop landscape in the early 1990s, whether your opinions run pro or con... Definitely a document of its time! (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue Guide To Country Music)
summary: "Don't let the bastards get you down..."

reviewText: This blu ray version was transferred very well for both audio and video.  Eddie Vedder's masters of war was a treat.  It captured the emotion of that song, like Dylan.  Neil Young was exceptional as was just about everyone on this fine concert.The only part I wasn't crazy about was Sinead O'Connor as the booing she got for her comments about the Pope turned into an emotional screechfest with her waiving off the band with just her voice alone.Other than that, this was one of the best concerts ever.  The musicians were a who's who of the finest rock, country, and folk performers ever.There is a  song everone will say should have been in the concert and wasn't.  As stated on the preconcert portion, if they included everything, they would have been on stage for a year.  My missing song was A Hard Rains Agonna Fall.Loved it..Buy yours for a permanent look at a great career and some the most important music ever written.

reviewText: When I think about modern song writers deserving of the The Gershswin Song Award I have to agree with Paul Simon and stump for Bob Dylan.  This concert makes a powerful testimony of such.  A diverse group of top-shelf artists come together to celebrate the Bob Dylan songbook here.  It may not be the absolute perfection of a tribute such as The Concert For George, but the songs are definitely here to trump any imperfection one may sight.  There is such a reverence to Bob presented by  these so diverse artists that this concert is more compelling than almost anything imaginable.  The widescreen presentation is perfection bringing a more than 20-year old event right up to the latest standards in sight and sound.  I really love the fact that this concert isn't a victim of excessive quick-cut edits as it invests the viewer deeply into each artist's rendition of the rich songs of Bob Dylan.  What a perfect "house band" consisting of Keltner, Dunn, Figg, Smith, et.al.  This stuff deserves repeated viewing due to the unbelievable richness of the songs with impassioned performances.  Sound, vision, and heart rarely combine in such a perfect union.  A concert for the ages.
summary: Content Trumps Performances...And The Performances Are Really Good...
Title: N/A

reviewText: BOB DYLAN-THE 30TH ANNIVERSARY CONCERT-VARIOUS ARTISTS: Appropriately nicknamed "BOB-FEST" by participant NEIL YOUNG, this long awaited celebration has finally made it to DVD twenty years after the fact, a "Who's Who" of admirers/performers backed by the redoubtable BOOKER T & THE MG'S. Folkies RICHIE HAVENS and THE CLANCY BROTHERS, soulsters STEVIE WONDER and THE O'JAYS, country outlaws WILLIE NELSON and JOHNNY CASH and bona fide rock stars GEORGE HARRISON, ERIC CLAPTON, TOM PETTY and RON WOOD all join forces to pay tribute to America's most complex, influential songwriter. From JOHN MELLENCAMP/organist AL KOOPER's) feisty kick off of LIKE A ROLLING STONE to ROGER MCGUINN's still buoyant TAMBOURINE MAN and WOODY's raspy DYLAN-like croak on SEVEN DAYS, it's a sweaty, scintillating showcase chock full of head-spinning highlights. This jam-packed party culminates in a superstar tag team of DYLAN/MCGUINN/PETTY/YOUNG/CLAPTON/HARRISON on reflective MY BACK PAGES, followed by everyone else for KNOCKIN' ON HEAVEN'S DOOR, a fitting finale for friends and fans forever tangled up in BOB's enduring mystique.RATING: FIVE ZIMMIE'S

reviewText: October 1992 an impressive group of artists singing and playing music of Dylan.One of the highlights of the show was the house band BookerT and The M.G's.They made every song special with their performance.Also Neil Young  has to be mentioned.He really felt himself with this "Bob fest"  and his version of "All Along The Watchtower" was a monumental  contribution to this concert.See and listen to all of the other stars  {Stevie Wonder,The Band,Lou Reed Richie havens,George Harrison and others}  and you won't forget this "Bob fest".At the end Bob Dylan himself  came to the stage and closed down this rock document the way only he  can.This celebration is a masterpiece for his music fans.

reviewText: Along with my friend Perry Lederman, I hitchhiked with Dylan back in 1961, and later helped to put on an early concert for Dylan in Ann Arbor, Michigan, so I was on the scene.I give this concert four stars because I appreciate that the intent of everyone involved was to honor Dylan, but I am sorry to say that I found most of the covers in this legendary concert actually painful to listen to compared to the originals.I came away understanding that we can't replace what there is only one of.

reviewText: In 1992, Dylan's record company, Columbia, put together an anniversary celebration of his first signing with the label.  This wasn't one of those charity events.  In fact the show was shown only on a pay per view television beyond the 18,000 ticket buyers at Madison Square Garden.  In 1993, an abridged version of the concert was put out on VHS tape.  In 2014, it is available for the first time on DVD and Blu ray in all its 173 minute glory (concert feature).  Sadly many of the featured artists have died, but the rest have trucked on to further fame and fortune.The Blu ray version comes in an interlaced 1080i format and have thankfully stretched the aspect ratio to 1.78:1 vs. the original 1.33:1 TV format.  I found nothing particularly glaringly offensive in the video conversion.  Colors seem accurate, skin tones are usual spot on.  In fact, I thought the video was surprisingly good.  Equally surprising was that the audio comes only with a PCM stereo option.  NOTE:  This Blu ray does NOT have a 5.1 Dolby Digital track noted in the Amazon description.  That's right, no surround.  And not uncompressed.  Still, I have to admit the audio wasn't bad.  In fact it was pretty good.  This is a good opportunity to try out one of the digital processing options on your AV receiver.  It works nicely.Everyone will have their favorites of course, but if you want to see the range of Dylan's writing and artistic covers try Richie Haven's beautiful rendition of "Just Like a Woman."  Then switch to either Neil Young's "All Along the Watchtower" or Johnny Winter's blistering "Highway 61 Revisited."  It's all good.  Extras include a 39 minute behind-the-scenes feauturette and 3 bonus performances (1.33:1 aspect ratio).  The track list is shown in Amazon's description.

reviewText: This is a tribute by various artists, some now have made their passing, e.g., Geo Harrison, eh so many others who were young at the time of this celebration.  It was questionable if Dylan would show up, but he did and at the finish performed 2-3 more of his songs.  The songs performed here are ALL DYLAN songs.  I sort of had to wonder what Bob was thinking as some of his songs were surely (I surmise) not performed as he might do them.  He's very fussy that way and constantly directs with motions, with the way he looks at band members all through.  He is DEFINITELY in charge w/extremely high standard he does meet, every time.  Yes, I am a Dylan devotee.  Anyway, I am not regretting purchasing both the CD and the DVD copies.  Each are a bit different, btw, in editing.  I've heard about four different versions of this Concert, recently another one on PBS.

reviewText: I had this concert on LaserDisc and I have always felt that Neil Young's performance of All Along the Watchtower was the standout. However there are many other fine performances including Tom Petty, Willie Nelson, and George Harrison. The songs are all so good, that it would be hard not to enjoy each performance. Some years ago, I obtained a DVD of the concert, but it was not complete. In particular, it did not have the Neil Young performance, so I was very disappointed with it. I am really pleased to have this very complete version in great looking video and great sounding audio. I bought the CD version of this as well. As Neil Young said,"Thanks for having Bobfest!".

reviewText: I saw this concert on VHS in the 90's.  I was lucky to find it at my video store.  Now, of course, it is practically unavailable on VHS, and not at all on DVD.  Why?  It is one of the  finest tribute concerts ever.  Each performance seems to rival the next for quality, and it goes on for at least a couple of hours.  For me, two of the highlights are Johnny Winter's revelatory version of Highway 61 Revisited and Vedder's Masters of War.  Who's here?  Oh, no one, just The Band, George Harrison, Eddie Vedder, Lou Reed, Neil Young, Roger Mcguinn and anyone the producers asked. Now, a lineup like that can lead either to epiphany or a terrible mistake.  Luckily, the former was the result.  One day it will go to DVD (how much longer they can ignore it may depend on the sagacity of whoever is minding Dylan's business end). and then everyone may get to experience this unforgettable night.

reviewText: I have both the VHS version of this show, as well as the lazer disc edition, and watched it live on HBO.  I rank this mega-super-star event right up there with Woodstock and Live Aid as one of the best concerts of all time. The line-up was all A-list including Stevie Wonder, Johnny Cash and June, Lou Reed, Neil Young, Johnny Winter, Tom Petty, Roger McGuinn,  just to name a few, and a mega rare appearance by George Harrison performing two songs and participating in others. It will be interesting to see if they restore George's "lost" song in the show.  His version of "if Not For You" was not included in the commercial VHS or Lazer Disc release of the show. This concert also includes some lesser-known acts (at the time) including Tracy Chapman, Roseanne Cash,  and a truly haunting version of "Masters of War" by Eddie Vedder. All indications are that this is a first-class release in terms of the video and audio sourcing.  G.E. Smith who provided the Music Director and guitar duties for the show will hopefully sound better than ever.
summary: One of the top 5 best concerts in history
Title: N/A

reviewText: It is wonderful that this concert has finally been released on BluRay. The sound and picture IMHO is spectacular. I won't say much as most of it has been covered elsewhere. However, here are a couple of points. if you taped the original broadcast when it aired on PBS 20 odd years ago, KEEP THAT COPY AS WELL! Some editing has been done which removes some of the more enjoyable (and funny parts, at least for me). 1. When the Band plays, the person yelling "DANKO!" "DANKO!" is not there, as well as Mr. Danko himself saying "DOH!" as the band tunes up. Too bad, it was an old fashioned good moment, in the spirit of the band. 2. Lou Reed's song has been video edited, showing much more of the drums. This is fine and good, but some great shots of G.E. Smith in the original footage are gone. 3. The interviews are different, the new ones great, but some footage from Clapton's and the Band's have been edited out.Some other points: its too bad Booker T & the MGs (Gotta Serve Somebody) was left as a bonus track (the footage was not remastered or in wide screen). Also, I was shocked to see that John Hammond in the interview section. If he performed, couldn't that footage have been included? After all, his father DID give Bob his first recording contract. Were there other performances left out? Perhaps someone who attended could enlighten us.The bluray is good. However, for such a release, couldn't they have gone all out and released all that exists (interviews, performance footage, etc.)? Perhaps 2 versions, the original broadcast as well as this "new" version. That's not to be, regretfully. As I said, for those of you who remember the orginial broadcast and luckily have a copy, keep it as well. The omissions are glaring.
summary: Great concert finally released - but edited from original broadcast

reviewText: This is a fantastic concert and Dylan experience. I have it on LaserDisc which is gorgeous with CD quality sound. I also have the UK DVD which appears to be a rip of the LaserDisc, which is almost as good.There are timeless performances here, never to be repeated again. For people who like Dylan we get 4 songs performed and great covers by top artists. For Dylan haters there are great songs with very little Dylan.I have watched this concert annually for 15 years or more. The whole thing makes a great Saturday night party. I could not be more excited, except maybe by some new video of The Beatles, to be getting it on Blu-Ray.  Haters are their own reward. This is as good as it gets.
summary: Thank you Columbia / Sony gods for releasing this concert
